definition: SMD jumper wire in resistor form.
The frequency at which a filter's output drops to 70.7% of its passband value, corresponding to half power.
Oscilloscope probe with 10:1 attenuation.
Signal path that blocks DC and passes only the time-varying component.
How close a measurement reading is to the true value.
Oscilloscope probe with a built-in amplifier at the tip, presenting very low capacitance (~1 pF) and high impedance.
Logarithmic capacitance loss over time in Class II and III ceramic capacitors.
SI unit of electric current.
Frequency expressed in radians per second: ω = 2πf.
The product of RMS voltage and RMS current, measured in volt-amperes (VA).
Instrument feature that automatically selects the measurement range.
IC package with solder balls on the bottom surface instead of pins on the perimeter.
Switching power supply topology that produces an output voltage higher than its input.
A path between two nodes in a circuit, carrying a single current.
Switching topology that can produce an output voltage either higher or lower than the input, with inverted polarity in the basic form.
Switching power supply topology that produces an output voltage lower than its input.
Voltage drop across an ammeter's internal shunt resistor.
Capacitor placed near an IC's power pins to supply instantaneous current demands and shunt high-frequency noise to ground.
Class I ceramic dielectric.
Vintage resistor type made from a solid slug of carbon and binder.
Electrical connection to the equipment's metal chassis or frame.
Protection component (typically a diode or TVS) that limits voltage excursions by conducting when a threshold is exceeded.
An instrument's or amplifier's ability to ignore voltage that appears equally on both inputs.
Inductor core made from magnetic particles suspended in resin.
The standard engineering convention: current flows from positive to negative.
Large area of copper on a PCB layer, typically connected to ground or power.
SI unit of electric charge.
Capacitor in series with a signal path that passes AC while blocking DC.
Temperature above which a ferroelectric ceramic's dielectric properties degrade sharply.
A PCB trace intentionally severed, usually as a rework modification.
Loss of capacitance in ceramic capacitors when DC voltage is applied.
Signal path that passes all frequencies including DC.
The resistance of an inductor's winding measured at DC.
Power measured in decibels referenced to 1 milliwatt.
Voltage in decibels referenced to 0.775 V (the voltage that produces 1 mW into 600 Ω).
Voltage in decibels referenced to 1 volt.
Placing capacitors near IC power pins to supply instantaneous switching current and prevent noise from propagating through the power distribution network.
Mathematical technique for converting between triangle (delta) and star (wye) resistor network topologies.
A voltage or current source whose value is controlled by another voltage or current elsewhere in the circuit.
Reducing a component's maximum allowable power, voltage, or current as operating conditions (typically temperature) move away from the rated conditions.
Insulating material between capacitor plates that determines capacitance, voltage rating, stability, and loss characteristics.
The fundamental bench instrument for measuring voltage, current, and resistance.
Dots placed on transformer winding symbols to indicate which terminals have the same instantaneous polarity.
The slope of the I-V curve at a specific operating point (dV/dI).
Physical connection to the earth, typically through the building's grounding system.
Power dissipated by circulating currents induced in a conductive core by the changing magnetic field.
Polarized capacitor using a liquid or polymer electrolyte to achieve high capacitance density.
The physical movement of electrons from negative to positive.
A single resistance value that replaces a series, parallel, or complex combination of resistors for analysis purposes.
The effective series resistance inside a capacitor, representing all resistive losses.
Parasitic inductance in a capacitor from its leads, internal connections, and plate geometry.
SI unit of capacitance.
Ceramic magnetic core material made from iron oxide compounds.
Capacitor using plastic film as the dielectric.
Multi-sheet schematic where all sheets exist at the same hierarchy level, connected by net names.
The voltage spike produced when current through an inductor is suddenly interrupted.
Diode placed across an inductive load to provide a safe current path when the driving switch opens.
A named electrical connection that spans multiple schematic sheets without explicit wiring.
Voltage spike on the ground network caused by fast-changing currents flowing through resistive and inductive ground paths.
A continuous copper layer on a PCB dedicated to ground.
SI unit of inductance.
SI unit of frequency.
IC power connection that exists in the component model but is not explicitly shown on the schematic symbol.
Schematic organized as a top-level block diagram with each block implemented as a separate sheet.
Duration that a capacitor can sustain a load after the input power is removed.
Energy dissipated in a magnetic core each AC cycle as magnetic domains reverse direction.
Generalized resistance for AC circuits, including both resistive (real) and reactive (imaginary) components.
Selecting load impedance to maximize power transfer from a source.
The property of a component that resists changes in current by storing energy in a magnetic field.
The impedance presented by a circuit or instrument at its input terminals.
The large transient current drawn when power is first applied to a circuit, typically caused by charging initially discharged capacitors.
Degradation of a dielectric material leading to increased leakage current or catastrophic short circuit.
The product of voltage and current at any specific moment: P(t) = V(t) × I(t).
Non-contact temperature measurement tool that reads infrared radiation from a surface.
Random voltage noise generated by thermal motion of electrons in any resistor.
SI unit of energy.
The sum of currents entering a node equals the sum of currents leaving.
The sum of voltage drops around any closed loop equals zero.
Small, undesired current flowing through a nominally insulating path.
A circuit that obeys the superposition principle: the response to a sum of inputs equals the sum of the individual responses.
The effect of connecting a load to a circuit, which draws current and may change the operating voltage.
Any closed path through a circuit, traversing one or more branches and returning to the starting node.
The energy storage medium in inductors and transformers.
Physical deformation of a magnetic core material caused by the changing magnetic field.
Unit of electric charge commonly used to rate battery capacity.
Occurs when load resistance equals the source's Thevenin resistance.
Systematic circuit analysis method that applies KVL around independent loops (meshes) and solves for loop currents.
Through-hole resistor type with low noise, tight tolerance, and good temperature stability.
The property of some components (especially ceramic capacitors) to generate voltage when subjected to mechanical vibration, due to the piezoelectric effect.
Magnetic coupling between adjacent inductors or windings.
A label applied to a wire or connection in a schematic that replaces physical wire drawings.
An explicit marker on a schematic indicating that an IC pin is intentionally left unconnected.
A junction where two or more branches meet in a circuit.
Systematic circuit analysis method that applies KCL at each node and solves for node voltages.
The approximate or stated voltage under no-load or standard conditions.
Any linear circuit reduced to a current source (I_n) in parallel with a resistance (R_n).
Negative Temperature Coefficient resistor whose resistance decreases with temperature.
SI unit of electrical resistance.
The fundamental relationship between voltage, current, and resistance.
The voltage measured across a source's terminals when no load is connected.
Coupling device between the circuit under test and the oscilloscope input.
The impedance a circuit presents at its output terminals.
Unintended capacitance present between conductors, component leads, PCB traces, and other structures.
Unintended inductance in component leads, wires, and PCB traces.
Generation of voltage from mechanical stress in certain materials.
The functional label of an IC pin (e.g., CLK, RESET, VCC).
The physical location identifier of an IC pin on the package.
The directional convention for voltage measurement.
A connection point in a hierarchical schematic that links a sub-sheet to the level above.
A three-terminal variable resistor with an adjustable wiper contact.
Inductor core made from iron particles with insulating gaps between them.
An accounting of all power sources, conversions, and dissipation in a system.
Reduction in a component's maximum allowable power dissipation at temperatures above a specified threshold.
The ratio of real power to apparent power.
Schematic symbols (VCC, VDD, 3V3, 5V, GND) representing global power connections.
The maximum continuous power a component can dissipate at a specified ambient temperature without exceeding its maximum operating temperature.
A measure of ratio.
The consistency of repeated measurements.
The distortion introduced by a measurement probe's input impedance (resistive and capacitive) on the circuit being measured.
A component whose resistance increases with temperature.
The current drawn by a circuit when no signal is applied and no load is driven.
Power that cycles back and forth between source and reactive components (capacitors, inductors) without performing net work.
The power actually dissipated as heat or converted to useful work, measured in watts.
The unique identifier for each component on a schematic and PCB: R1, C2, U3, Q4, etc.
The assumed direction of current flow or voltage polarity assigned during circuit analysis.
The node assigned zero volts in nodal analysis.
How well a voltage source maintains its output under varying load conditions.
The smallest change in a measured quantity that an instrument can display.
Manual modifications to a PCB after assembly: bodge wires, component swaps, cut traces.
AC current superimposed on DC current flowing through a capacitor.
The effective value of a time-varying signal.
The current at which an inductor's core can no longer store additional magnetic energy, causing inductance to drop.
The frequency at which a capacitor's ESL resonates with its capacitance, causing impedance to reach a minimum.
A low-value precision resistor placed in a current path so that the voltage drop across it indicates the current flowing.
Components connected end-to-end so that the same current flows through each.
Components connected across the same two nodes so that they share the same voltage.
Inductor with a magnetic structure that contains the magnetic field, reducing radiated interference and susceptibility to external fields.
The current that flows when a source's output terminals are connected together.
Low-value resistor used inside ammeters and current-sense circuits to convert current into a measurable voltage.
Standard multipliers for units: tera (10¹²), giga (10⁹), mega (10⁶), kilo (10³), milli (10⁻³), micro (10⁻⁶), nano (10⁻⁹), pico (10⁻¹²), femto (10⁻¹⁵).
The reference point for signal voltages in a circuit.
Three or four digit code: for a 3-digit code, the first two digits are significant and the third is the exponent.
An RC or RCD network that absorbs energy from switching transients, reducing voltage spikes and ringing.
The process of "turning off" independent sources to find equivalent resistance: voltage sources become short circuits; current sources become open circuits.
A voltage source with low output impedance, meaning its voltage barely changes when load current varies.
Very high-capacitance component (farads to hundreds of farads) used for energy storage and extended holdup time.
In nodal analysis, a boundary drawn around a voltage source and its two adjacent nodes, allowing KCL to be applied to the combined region.
In mesh analysis, a combined loop formed when a current source appears in a branch shared by two meshes.
The principle that in a linear circuit, the total response equals the sum of the responses due to each independent source acting alone.
Polarized capacitor with high volumetric efficiency.
A resonant LC circuit that stores energy by oscillating between the electric field of the capacitor and the magnetic field of the inductor.
The change in a component's value per degree Celsius, usually expressed in ppm/°C.
Imaging device that maps surface temperatures across a PCB or system.
Heat transfer between physically adjacent components.
Interface material applied between a component and heatsink to fill microscopic air gaps and reduce thermal resistance.
Resistance to heat flow, analogous to electrical resistance.
A positive feedback loop where increased temperature causes increased current (or power), which further increases temperature.
Any linear circuit reduced to a voltage source (V_th) in series with a resistance (R_th).
The most common SMD resistor type.
Precision SMD resistor with tight tolerance (0.1% or better), excellent tempco, and low noise.
Marking system where the first two digits are significant and the third is a power-of-ten multiplier in picofarads.
The characteristic response time of an RC or RL circuit.
The allowable deviation of a component's actual value from its nominal value, expressed as a percentage.
The accumulated uncertainty when multiple components' tolerances combine in a circuit.
A brief, fast-changing voltage or current event.
Oscilloscope feature that synchronizes the display to a specific event on the waveform, producing a stable, readable display.
Power factor of 1, meaning voltage and current are perfectly in phase.
Inductor with an open magnetic path that allows the magnetic field to radiate.
SI unit of electric potential difference.
The change in a component's value with applied voltage.
A network (typically two resistors in series) that produces an output voltage proportional to the input voltage.
SI unit of power.
Unit of energy.
The moving contact in a potentiometer that slides along the resistive element, creating a variable voltage divider.
Precision resistor made by winding resistance wire on a form.
Class II ceramic dielectric rated for -55°C to +85°C with ±15% capacitance variation over temperature.
Class II ceramic dielectric rated for -55°C to +125°C with ±15% capacitance variation over temperature.
Class III ceramic dielectric with very high capacitance density but terrible stability: +22% / -82% over temperature range.
